text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on January 22 in history.
1440 - Ivan III The Great, Grand Duke of Muscovy, born. He strengthened the monarchy and made Muscovy a great power, initiating the conquest of Ukraine.
1561 - Francis Bacon, English statesman, essayist and philosopher, born. His most celebrated work was his "Novum Organum", a broad investigation of knowledge.
1760 - In the Seven Years War the French were defeated by the British at the Battle of Wandiwash, India.
1771 - Spain reluctantly agreed that the Falkland Islands were British territory. The islands had been in dispute since they were discovered in 1592.
1775 - Andre Ampere, French physicist and founder of electromagnetics, born.

1788 - Lord (George Gordon) Byron, English romantic poet, born. Also much admired in Europe for his aspirations for political liberty, he joined in the fight for Greek independence shortly before his death.
1840 - The first British colonists arrived at Port Nicholson, New Zealand.
1879 - In The Zulu War 830 British troops were massacred at Isandlwana, near Rorke's Drift.
1901 - Queen Victoria of England died, after reigning for 63 years. She holds the record for the longest-reigning queen in the World, and is 4th in the list of longest-reigning monarchs.

1903 - Colombia rejected the Hay-Herran Pact offered by the Americans, under which control of the Panama Canal would be given to the U.S. Only when Panama declared itself independent of Colombia later that year did the U.S. gain control.
1905 - "Bloody Sunday" occurred in St Petersburg, when the Czar's troops killed 500 protesting workers.
1909 - U Thant, Burmese diplomat and secretary-general of the U.N., born. Thant played a major role during the Cuban missile crisis.
1924 - Ramsay MacDonald took over from Stanley Baldwin as British prime minister.
1941 - Allied forces captured the Libyan port of Tobruk from the Italians.
1944 - The allies landed at Anzio, Italy, in an operation codenamed Shingle.
1945 - The land route to China, the Ledo road across Burma from India to China, reopened.
1964 - Kenneth Kaunda was sworn in as Northern Rhodesia's first prime minister.
1966 - President Nkrumah of Ghana inaugurated the Volta River hydro-electric scheme.
1968 - A U.S. B-52 bomber carrying unarmed hydrogen bombs crashed near Thule, Greenland.
1972 - In Brussels, the Treaty of Accession to the EEC was signed by Britain, Denmark, Ireland and Norway, effective January 1, 1973.
1973 - A Royal Jordanian Airlines Boeing 707, bringing Moslem pilgrims back from Mecca, burst into flames on landing at Kano airport, Nigeria, killing 176.
1973 - Lyndon B. Johnson, Democratic U.S. president from 1963-69, died.
1980 - In the Soviet Union, dissident physicist Dr Andrei Sakharov was arrested, stripped of his honours and exiled to Gorky from Moscow.
1981 - Fowzi Nejad, only surviving member of the group which attacked and took over the Iranian Embassy in London in April 1980, was jailed for life.
1995 - A suicide bomber killed 19 people, mostly Israeli soldiers, near a bus station where troops wait for transport into the occupied West Bank.
1996 - The pro-Moscow Moslem spiritual leader of Tajikistan, Fatkhulla Sharipov, was assassinated.
